content:
--- Session 202601282330 Start ---

 --Patient ID 1748--

--- Session 202601282330 Start ---

 --Patient ID 1748--
Good morning, Mr. Anderson. To start, can you share your preferred name and pronouns if you're comfortable?
My name's Jared. I go by he/him. I'm an IT guy, so...

Thank you for sharing, Jared. This session will involve discussing your concerns and working together to find ways to support you. The session will last about 50 minutes. Do you have any questions about how this will work?
No, I think I understand. I guess I'm just hoping we can work on how to stop seeing unexpected things as such a big deal. It’s starting to affect my job performance, honestly.
I appreciate your hope to address these challenges, Jared. Are you comfortable with us moving forward with this discussion today?

Yeah, I guess so... I mean, it’s not like I’ve got a better option. The whole thing about these thoughts taking up so much space in my head is starting to really wear on me, you know? Like, last week I had to work late and my plans for the evening just... vanished. I spent the whole night stewing about it.
It sounds like these thoughts can be really draining, Jared. Is there anything specific you'd like to clarify or discuss before we move forward?
No, I think we covered the main points. Maybe just how it's affecting work... but I'm not sure where to start.
--- Phase 1 End ---

It sounds like these patterns have been with you for a long time and are starting to take a bigger toll. Can you describe how this issue has changed or evolved for you since your teenage years, especially in the past year or so?

It’s gotten worse over time. Back then, it was just things like canceled games or bad days at school—stuff I could brush off eventually. Now, it’s more about my job and expectations. If a project goes off-script or I work late like last week, I spiral into thinking the whole day is ruined, and it bleeds into weekends. The anxiety feels heavier, like I can’t shake it even when I try to remind myself there’s still time to enjoy things. It’s starting to affect my teammates too, which makes me feel isolated and worse.
Thank you for sharing that—I appreciate your openness about how this has been affecting your life. As we move forward, can you tell me what you’re most hoping to achieve through counseling right now?

I guess the main thing is learning how to stop seeing every unexpected change as a total loss. I want to be able to roll with the punches without my whole day feeling ruined. Like, if a meeting gets canceled or a project shifts, I don’t want to spiral into this ‘wasted time’ mindset that drags me down for hours. I’m hoping we can work on practical tools—maybe ways to reframe those moments or build better habits around adjusting to changes without it eating at me. My job’s starting to suffer, and I don’t want to be that guy who’s always tense about things not going exactly as planned.

It makes sense that work stress has amplified these patterns recently. Let’s explore the timeline a bit more—what specific changes or events in the past year do you think have made things feel more unmanageable now compared to before?

The biggest change was taking on a new project at work last year—there were constant last-minute shifts in priorities, which made it hard to stick to any routine. I started staying late a lot more, and when I finally had free time, I’d obsess over how I ‘wasted’ the day if something derailed my plans, like a meeting running late. It’s like the stress from work bled into everything else, and I couldn’t shake the feeling that I was failing to ‘optimize’ my time, even on weekends.
--- Phase 2 End ---

I appreciate your openness in discussing how work stress and rigid expectations have affected your life. Let’s explore a bit more about your support system—could you share how your friends have helped you cope, even if it’s challenging to open up about these thoughts? Also, have you faced any traumatic or difficult experiences in your life that might connect to how you handle unexpected changes or stress?

My friends are good about checking in on me, like buying me coffee or dragging me out for a walk when I’ve been stuck in my head. But I don’t really talk to them about the… you know, the ‘wasted day’ stuff. It feels too personal, like they’d think I’m overreacting. As for tough experiences… I guess growing up, I was always Type-A with schedules and projects. In high school, a canceled robotics competition made me feel like I’d ‘lost’ weeks of prep time. It’s just… built up since then. No single trauma, just this habit of seeing disruptions as failures. Frustrating, right?
--- Phase 3 End ---

I appreciate you sharing how these thoughts impact your life, Jared. It’s important we ensure your safety as we move forward. Have you ever had thoughts of intentionally harming yourself or ending your life?

No, I haven’t had thoughts like that. My struggles are more about anxiety and feeling like I lose control when plans change, but I’ve never wanted to harm myself. I’ve focused on trying to manage the stress through routines or talking to friends, even if it’s not working great right now.

I appreciate your openness, Jared. To better understand your current state, have you noticed any changes in your sleep patterns or energy levels recently—such as needing less sleep, feeling unusually energetic, or having difficulty slowing down?

Yeah, my sleep’s been off. I’ll stay up late ruminating about things that went wrong during the day, then I’m too wired to wind down even if I want to. It’s like my brain fixates on the 'wasted' time and I can’t shake it. Lately, I’ve been waking up around 3 a.m. trying to re-plan my day, which just makes me exhausted the next day. My energy’s been all over the place—drained most of the time, but with bursts of restless energy when I’m stuck in these thought loops.

Thank you for sharing so openly, Jared. It sounds like these sleep disruptions and energy fluctuations are taking a real toll. Let’s explore another aspect—have you ever felt unusually energetic or restless to the point where it was hard to slow down, or spent a lot of time doing many things at once without seeing a problem?

No, I haven't experienced that. My energy issues are more about feeling drained or anxious when plans go off track. I get really tense when unexpected things happen, but I don't feel 'overly energetic' or like I can't slow down. My Type-A side drives me to stick to schedules, but that's more about control than restlessness.

I appreciate your clarity, Jared. To cover another important area—have you used alcohol, cannabis, or other substances in the past month, and if so, how often? This helps us understand any factors that might be influencing your energy or mood patterns.

No, I haven’t used alcohol, cannabis, or other substances in the past month. I’ve tried to avoid relying on anything like that because I want to address this mentally rather than mask it. Though... sometimes I wonder if stress might push me toward it eventually, but not recently.

I appreciate your thoughtful approach to managing stress, Jared. To ensure we cover all relevant factors, are you currently taking any medications or supplements, including prescription, over-the-counter, or herbal products?
No, I'm not on any medications or supplements right now. I haven't needed any prescriptions for this, and I don't take anything regularly—just maybe a multivitamin occasionally, but that's it.

I appreciate your honesty, Jared. To ensure we cover all important areas, have you ever experienced hallucinations (hearing, seeing, or sensing things others don’t) or held beliefs that feel unusual or hard to let go of, even when others disagree?

No, I haven’t experienced hallucinations. As for beliefs, I guess my issue is more about rigid thinking around schedules—like labeling days as 'wasted' if plans change. It’s not that I hold odd beliefs, but this pattern feels deeply ingrained, even if it’s irrational.

I appreciate your detailed insights, Jared. To ensure we address all relevant factors, do you have any medical conditions such as thyroid issues, sleep apnea, chronic pain, or a history of head injuries that might be relevant here?

No, I don’t have any of those medical conditions. I’ve always been pretty healthy physically—my sleep issues and fatigue are tied to the stress and anxiety from my thought patterns, not any underlying medical problem. I guess that’s why I’m here, to work on the mental side of things.

I appreciate your thoroughness in describing your experiences, Jared. To conclude this phase, can you share what supports you have in your life that help you cope with stress or difficult times—like friends, family, or activities that provide comfort or distraction?

I’ve got a few close friends who check in with me, like grabbing coffee or going for walks when I seem off. But I usually keep the bigger stuff—like the 'wasted day' thoughts—to myself. I worry they’d think I’m being too dramatic. For stress, I’ll sometimes get lost in video games or tinkering with old electronics at home. It’s a way to zone out, but it’s more escape than solving anything. My strict routine helps too—sticking to a schedule feels stable, even if it’s my own cage sometimes.
--- Phase 4 End ---

Jared, based on our discussion, I understand that your lifelong tendency to label unexpected disruptions as 'wasted' has intensified with recent work stressors, creating a cycle of rumination and exhaustion. This pattern began in adolescence, was reinforced by a high school competition cancellation, and now interacts with job demands that leave little room for flexibility. The formulation suggests perfectionism and fear of vulnerability as core themes, with work pressures and rigid self-expectations perpetuating the issue—while your proactive approach to care and support system are key strengths. What did I miss or misunderstand about your experience?

You got the main points. One thing you might’ve missed is that the high school competition was a robotics event—I’d spent weeks prepping, and when it was canceled, it felt like I’d literally lost time. That stuck with me. Also, I haven’t told friends how much this actually weighs on me because I’m scared they’ll think I’m overreacting, so I keep it private. Oh, and I’ve never been to therapy before, so this is all new territory. The stress isn’t extreme, but it’s nonstop, and it’s starting to eat into weekends and make me feel alone even when I’m around people.
--- Phase 5 End ---

--- Session Summary ---

Subjective: Reports chronic anxiety around unexpected disruptions worsening since adolescence, intensified by work stress last year. Sleep disturbances (3 a.m. rumination, exhaustion), rigid scheduling, and 'wasted time' rumination. High school robotics competition cancellation (age ~18) solidified fear of time loss. No suicidal ideation or substance use in past month. Avoids discussing emotional struggles with friends due to fear of being perceived as 'overreacting.'

Objective: Occupational impairment noted (team dynamics, weekend isolation). Sleep study recommended for insomnia severity. No acute safety concerns. No medications/supplements in use. Cognitive rigidity around time optimization observed. Support system includes friends (superficial engagement) and solitary coping (video games, electronics).

Assessment: Perfectionism and fear of vulnerability perpetuate anxiety cycle. Work stress amplifies rigid thought patterns. Sleep disturbance likely exacerbates emotional dysregulation. No psychotic features or medical comorbidities. Low baseline but persistent stress impacting work-life balance.

Plan: Cognitive restructuring for 'wasted time' narratives. Sleep hygiene education. Gradual exposure to schedule flexibility. Explore safe disclosure strategies with friends. Monitor work stressors. Rule out insomnia disorder with sleep assessment.

--- End Summary ---
